switch statement

　Using the switch statement allows you to write if ... else if more concisely. It follows the syntax below.

switch(base_expression)
{
case condition_expression1 :

case condition_expression2 :

:
:

default:

:
:
}

　In base_expression, you write an expression which is evaluated first. You also write an expression for the condition_expression? following the case labels inside the switch block.
　Each condition_expression? is evaluated sequentially within the block. If the result matches the base_expression, execution begins from that point. If there is no match for a condition_expression?, the lines and statements written in between are ignored. Additionally, once a match is found, subsequent case or default labels are ignored (and execution continues through them).
　The default: label can be omitted, but if it is present, the statements following it will be executed by default if no other matches occur.
　To exit the block, write break;. Be careful, as it is a common mistake to forget the break and end up executing the contents of the next case.


Example:
    switch(a)
    {
    case 0:
        inform("a is 0");
        break;
    case 1:
        inform("b is 1");
        break;
    case 2:
        inform("b is 2");
        break;
    default:
        inform("b is neither 0, 1, nor 2");
    }


    switch(a)
    {
    case 0:
    case 1: // Since there is no break, it passes through here if case is 0
        inform("a is 0 or 1");
        break;
    case 2:
        inform("a is 2");
    } // Since there is no default, nothing is executed if a is not 0, 1, or 2


    switch(a)
    {
    case b+1: // Expressions can also be specified after case
        inform("a==b+1");
        break;
    case c+b:
        inform("a==c+b");
    }

    switch(str)
    {
    case "abcde": // Strings can also be specified
        type=1;
        break;
    case "fghij":
        type=2;
        break;
    }
